column9: Code uses from rinoh.styleds import * This hides the imoported objects and might lead to collisions in the future if objects of the same name are imported with wildcards.  styleds is a collection of imports, aimed to ease related imports. I copied the used imports from there and deleted the unused ones.  This adds many imports and does not  benefits from styleds, so this is a downside of fixing this alert.
column11: rather long, no methods or structure

column9: The constructor of AdobeFontMetricsParser had 14 branches. I extracted _process_line with the content of the loop going over lines.
column13: extracted method coupled with its caller

column9: The method write_log had 6 nesting levels, while the recommendation is at most 5. I extracted two nested methods,  _log_entries and in it _handle_source. The methods extraction also fixed too-many-branches and too-many-statements in that method.
column13: Less complex code – nesting, branches, and statements

column9: The constructors, that handles many format values, had too many branches. I extracting handling format 4 into a dedicated method.

column9: Method children had many branches computing the text variable. I extracted those base on the type value into _handle_type and replaces these branches with a single one, checking if the type is relevant.

column9: File indeed has many lines. A single dictionary has 1,000+ lines. However it is a reference of other Adobbe structure. Moving the data to csv won’t help and prevent python check of data. __all__ = ("Hyphenator") while it should be a list (e.g. __all__ = ["Hyphenator"]). Seems like a bug. https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44834/what-does-all-mean-in-python

column9: File has 1,023 lines, above the recommended 1,000. File has many small classes, starting with base ones like Integer. It seems that the file will benefit from splitting the classes into some files. However, the choice of files requires more familiarity with its content.

Method read_dictionary_or_stream of class PDFObjectReader had 6 nesting levels. I extracted _handle_filter that takes only the dictionary as a parameter and encapsulates the creation of the stream_filter.
